L E G E N D " The purpose of this map is to indicate to tourists some of the more outstanding
o a complete and comprehensive list, but rather as indicative of the hundreds o

£

oints of historical, scenic and general interest in Maryland. The points of interest selected are not intended as
interesting places scattered throughout the State. It is suggested that tourists wherever possible make inquiries

at all Maryland State Police Sub-Stations for more detailed directions for reaching the various places. ~ For convenience, the State has been divided into four sections: namely,
Eastern Shore, Southern Maryland, North Central, and Western Maryland, and the principal points of interest have been generally located by the indication of either the U. S. or Maryland route numbers.

EASTERN SHORE OF MARYLAND

“Conowingo Dam’’—at Conowingo—second largest hydro-elec-

tric development in the United States. U. S. Route No. 1.

“Port DEeprosiT’”’—on the banks of the Susquehanna River—
renowned as the termination of Capt. John Smith’s voyage of
exploration up the Chesapeake Bay. Home of the Tome In-
stitute, a boys’ school of national reputation.

“Principio FurNAce''—midway between Havre de Grace and
Elkton. One of the first iron furnaces in this Country. U.S.
Route No, 40.

“PArTRingE Hivn”—Evkron—built prior to 1750 by Colonel
Henry Hollingsworth, a noted patriot, who during the Revo-
lutionary War, was engaged in the manufacture of gun barrels
and bayonets for the Council of Safety of Maryland.
U. S. Route No. 40.

“Bounemia ManNour’’—beautiful estate of Augustine Herman,
a Bohemian by birth—the first person to_receive his citizenship
in Maryland by Act of the Assembly. U. S. Route No. 213.

“OLp Surewssury Cuurch’’—near Locust Grove—one of the
thirty parishes- of the Church of England laid out in the
province of Maryland in 1692 by authority of an act of the
provincial assembly. U. S§. Route No. 213,

CHESTERTOWN-—

a. ‘“‘Pearce House''—built in 1735 as a residence for British
customs officials.

b. *“Washington College''—oldest college in Maryland and
eleventh oldest in the United States. First college to bear
the’ name of the Father of OQur Country by his personal
consent.

U. S. Route No. 213.

“St. Luke’s Cuurcn’’—at Church Hill—present church built
in 1730. One of the original parish churches of Maryland.
U. S. Route No. 213 and Maryland Routes No. 300 and

o. 19.

“Winton""—near Melfield—once the. summer home of Judge
Richard Tilghman Earle—now the summer home of Mr. and
Mrs. John J. Raskob of Delaware.

“Wye Oax”’—at Wye Mills just south of Centerville—said to
be over 400 years old and has a spread of 140 feet. U. S.
Route No. 213 and Maryland Route No. 404. !

“Kent Istand”’—Wm, Claiborne established a trading. post
and fort at the southern end of this island in 1631. Lord
Baltimore’s rights were reserved, which led to serious con-
troversy until taken by armed forces in 1637.

“Oup Frienns’ Meerine House”—at Easton—built in 1684
by the Society of Friends and said to be the oldest frame
building dedicated to religious meetings in America. U. S.
Route No. 213 and Maryland Route No. 17.

“Wyr House”’—the home of the Lloyd family for nine genera-
tions, and regarded as one of the show places of Maryland.
Maryland Route No. 17,

“PrLimuiMMon’’—near Easton—the ancestral home of the wife
of Lieut.-Col. Tench Tilghman, who carried the glad tidings
of the surrender of the British at Yorktown to the Conti-
nental Congress at Philadelphia. On this old estate 'is a
monument to Tench Tilghman,

“RarcrLirre Maxnour’’—on the Tred Avon River—a splendid
example of colonial architecture and noted for its boxwood
gardens,

“Frazier’s Frars’'—east of the Choptank River above Dover
Bridge—about five miles east of Easton. One of the finest
specimens of colonial architecture on the Upper Choptank.
U. S. Route No. 213. :

The vicinity of Cambridge is the sportsman’s Mecca; many
summer homes and hunting lodges are located here.

“Summer Home or THeE Duronts'’—near Cambridge.

“Summer Home or WaLTer P. CurysLer’’—near Cambridge.

“Op Trinity Cuurcu”’—-near Cambridge—built about 1665,
familiarly known as ‘“The Old Church.” A handsome red
velvet cushion sent to the church by Queen Anne, and upon
which she is said to have knelt to receive her crown is still
in possession of the church and in a perfect state of preser-
vation,

Here, in the vicinity of Cambridge and Oxford, the Acadians
found a haven of welcome alter their exile from Grand Pre,
Nova Scotia, in 1755. There are many descendants of the
Acadians in Dorchester and Talbot Counties.

Section south of Taylor's Island is center of the muskrat indus-
try, the income from which amounts to approximately
$2,500,000 annually.

“Green HiLn Cuurcu’’-—several miles above White Haven on
the Wicomico River. Built in 1733, one of the original
parish churches laid out in 1692, ;

SaLispury—known as Handy's Landing until 1732, in which
year the town of Salisbury was laid out. There are a num-
ber of old colonial mansions still standing in or near this now
thriving town, among them:

a. ‘‘Pemberton Hall”—about six miles from Salisbury.

b. “‘Cherry Hill’’—about two miles from Salisbury.

c. “‘Poplar Hill Mansion"—facing down Williams Street in
Salisbury.

U. S. Routes No. 13 and No. 213 and Maryland Route

o. 12.

“Wasuiveron Hoter—Princess Anne—built by John Done
on lot No. 15, when Princess Anne was laid out in lots be-
fore the Revolutionary War. An interesting feature of this
old inn, a survival of Colonial days, is the double staircase—
one for the ladies whose large hoop skirts required abundant
space and the other for the gentlemen who admired them
from a respectful distance, ascending and descending. U. S.
Route No. 13,

“Cuase House”——about two miles south of Princess Anne—
built in 1713; the birthplace of Samuel Chase, one of the
signets of the Declaration of Independence.

“DeaL IsLanp”—in Somerset County—one of the greatest sec-
tions in the Country for hunting wild fowl. Here also is the
soft crab center of the world.

“TANGIER Sounp’’—greater part of this famous sound ‘lies
within Somerset County—this body of water produces more
valuable sea foods than any similar waters in the Country.

“CrisFierp”’—in Somerset County—the crabbing center of the
United States. Here the famous Maryland Crab is caught,
packed and shipped to all parts of the Country. Crisfield is
noted also for its Diamond Back Terrapin nurseries. Here
thousands of this rare Maryland delicacy are raised and
shipped to every State in the Union. U, S. Route No. 413.

“Art Harrows Cuurcu’’~—at Snow Hill—built in 1748, U. S.
Route No. 113 and Maryland Route No. 12,

“Ocean City”"—Maryland’s well-known seaside resort. Has
a summer population of over a half million persons., U. S.
Route No. 213.

*“CHINCOTEAGUE IsLAnD’—on the eastern shore of Virginia
near the Maryland line—noted for its wild ponies. A round-
up and sale is held on the island annually and draws inter-
ested spectators and buyers from all parts of the East. Chinco-
teague Bay is also noted for its salt oysters. Maryland Route

0. 13,
SOUTHERN MARYLAND

ANNAPOLIS—

a. “United States Naval Academy’—established in 1845 by
George Bancroft, then Secretary of the Navy,

b. “St. John's College’—originally King Wil{iam’s School ;
founded in 1696,

c. “Liberty Tree”’—on the campus of St. John's College—a
tulip poplar 150 feet high, said to be: years old.

d. “Hammond-Harwood House’'—built in 1777; one of the
finest examples of Georgian architecture in America.

e. “Paca House”—built in 1763 by Wm. Paca, one of the
signers of the Declaration of Independence. Now known
as Carvel Hall Hotel, °

f. *“Brice House’—built in 1745. Regarded as the hand-
somest house in a city of handsome old homes.

g. ‘‘State House''—here, on December 23, 1783, Washington
surrendered his commission to the Continental Congress.
Here also, Congress ratified the treaty with Great Britain
at the close of the Revolutionary War.

h. *St. Anne’s Church”~—built in 1699. Among its treasures
are the silver communion set presented by King William
III and the beautiful Sand’s Memorial Window in the
Nave, which, when exhibited by Tiffany at the Chicago
World’s Fair, won first prize for ecclesiastical art.

“Old State Treasury Building”’—built in 1694.

‘‘Home of Anthony Stewart’’—owner of the brig “Peggy

Stewart.”

“White Hall’’~—near Annapolis—one of the most famous

homes in Southern Maryland. Built in 1760, the sum-

mer home of Horatio Sharpe, one of the earliest Gov-

ernors of Maryland. g
U. 8. Route No, 50 and Maryland Route/No. 2.

“ALr Harrows Chnukcu’—on the State Road from Annapolis
to Solomons. Built about 1692, Maryland Route No. 2.
“St. James’ Cuurcu''—at Herring Creek—about four miles
low Mt. Zion. Built about 1694, one of the original parish
churches of Maryland. Rebuilt in 1763 and present building

is still in use., Maryland Route No. 2.

“Laurer Race Track”—one of the finest tracks in the Coun-
try—where horse racing meets are held each Fall. U. S.
Route No. 1.

“University oF MaryrLanp”’—College Park—founded by the
merging in 1920 of the University of Maryland which was
founded in 1807 and the Maryland State Agricultural Col-
lege founded in 1856. Has campus of 300 acres and a farm
of 210 acres belonging to the college of agriculture, U, S.
Route No. 1.

“BLApENSBURG —where the American forces, composed of 500
seamen and marines with five pieces of artillery, under the
command of Commodore Joshua Barney, attempted to hold in
check the British army of veterans more than 5,000 strong.
U. S. Routes No. 1 and No. 50. -3

“GreenpeLt Community (Tucwerrtown)'’—project of the
Resettlement Administration at Berwyn, U. S. Route No. 1.

“BeLAir”'—near Bowie—the old Governor Ogle place. It still
has all the features of an old English estate, with its park,
private race track and kennels.

“Bowie Race Track”—one of Maryland’s four famous tracks—
where horse racing programs are held annually in the Spring
and Fall,

“OLp Marrooro House”—Upper Marlboro. About 250 years
old. Maryland Routes No. 3 and No. 4.

“St. Pauvr’s Cuurcu’’—at Baden—built about 1694. An in-
teresting relic is a marble font said to have been presented
by Queen Anne and is still in use. Bishop Claggett, first
Bishop of the Episcopal Church to be ordained in America,
was twice rector of this church.

“Murperry Grove”’—near La Plata—home of John Hanson,
president of the first Continental Congress, which welcomed
General Washington officially on his return from receiving
the surrender of Cornwallis. Maryland Route No. 3.

Southern Maryland is noted for its excellent tobacco, and
tobacco raising is an important industry of the State. The
approximate value of the 1931 crop is estimated at about
$9,000,000.

“St., Tuomas’ Cuurcu AND. Burvine Grounp’’—at Chapel
Point—first home of the Jesuit priests in America.

“Curist Cuurcn’’—at Port Republic—built of bricks im-
ported from England in 1732. Maryland Route No. 2.

P
.

r

“Mipprenam CuareL’’——about six miles from Solomons—built
in 1699, one of the original parish churches of Maryland. The
bell in this church is the third oldest on the Atlantic seaboard
and was a gift of a British nobleman. Maryland Route

0. 2,

“Soromoxs IsrLanp”’—the harbor at Solomons is one of the
deepest natural harbors in the world, reaching a depth of
136 feet, and is an important center of the yacht and boat
building industry. The Dewey floating drydock was built
an tested here because there was no other harbor in the East
large enough for its construction. Solomons is considered
one of the finest” “fishing grounds” in the East. Maryland
Route No. 2.

“Tue Crirrs or CALvErT” —rise vertically from the Bay and
extend for 30 miles from Chesapeake Beach to Drum Point—
these cliffs contain fossiliferous strata of from ten to twenty
feet in thickness. :

“CrarLorte HaLn ScHoovr”—on the State Road to Leonard-
town. In 1774, the free schools of St. Mary’s, Charles and
Prince George's Counties - were united and Charlotte Hall
erected, Maryland Routes No. 5 and No. 6.

“Curist Crurcn’’—at Chaptico—one of the original parish -

churches of Maryland. Designed by Sir Christopher Wren,

the architect of St. Paul’s Cathedral, London. Maryland

Route No. 234. ;

“Porrar Hirr Cuurcu'’—at Valley Lee—about 12 miles from
Leonardtown. Oldest parish church in Maryland.

St. Mary’s Crry— s
a. “Chancellor’s Point’’—near St. Mary’s City—where the

“Ark” and the “Dove” landed in 1634. At a spot
near here, Leonard Calvert laid out St. Mary's City, the
first colony in Maryland. :

b. “Leonard Calvert Monument”—St. Mary's City—on the
site of the old mulberry tree under which Leonard Calvert
signed the treaty by which he bought 30 miles from the
Indian King in § . ; :

¢. “Trinity Church’—at St. Mary’s City—built of the bricks
of the first State House in Maryland on the site of the
old mulberry tree under which negotiations were made
between Leonard Calvert and King Yaocomico. The altar
and communion rail were made from the wood of the
old tree.

Maryland Route No. 5. : 3

“Cross Manor”—below St. Inigoes—built in 1642 by Thomas
Cornwaleys, Deputy Governor of Maryland. Said to be the
oldest house in the State, and noted for its boxwood hedges
nearly 300 years old, Maryland Route No. 5.

“Sr. Inicoes CHurcu’’—about two miles from St. Inigoes—
the oldest Catholic church in Maryland. The original church
property of 2,000 acres is still retained by the Jesuit Order.
Maryland Route No. §. )

“Point Looxoutr”’—0On the southeastern tip of St. Mary’s land,
where the Potomac flows into the Chesapeake. Maryland
Route No. 5. ’

NORTH CENTRAL MARYLAND

“DovcorEGAN Manor’'—near Ellicott City—beautiful old
colonial mansion. Ancestral home of Charles Carroll of Car-
rollton, a signer of the Declaration of Independence. U. S.
Route No. 40.

“Oriver Viapuct”’—at Ellicott City, a part of the original
Baltimore and Ohio Railroad line—the cornerstone for this
triple-arch structure was laid in 1829 and the bridge was
formally opened to traffic in 1830. During the same year,
the “Tom Thumb,” first steam engine in America, crossed
this bridge on its first trip, from Baltimore to Ellicott Mills,
U. S. Routes No. 40 and No. 29.

“BrookeviLLE —President Madison and his family took refuge
in this quaint old town when the British burned the city
of Washington in 1814, and the house which they occupied
is still standing. Maryland Route No. 97.

“Rockx Creek Park”—this lovely park, which begins in Wash-
ington, extends into Montgomery County. In this park is
located the United States National Zoological Gardens, con-
taining one of the most complete collections of wild animals,
reptiles, birds, fowl, etc., in the world.

“Greatr Fairs or THeE Poromac’’—In the rugged country of
Montgomery County, about 15 miles from Washington, the
river makes its most rapid descent in a series of beautiful
falls, and is unrivaled for scenic beauty in this section of
the Country.

FreEpERICK— ¢
a, “‘Home of Barbara Fritchie””—Here this famous character

of Civil War days lived “‘bowed with her four score years
and ten,” and by her intense patriotism inspired Whittier
to write “‘Barbara. Fritchie.” ,

b. ‘“The Taney House’’—home of Chief Justice Roger Brooke
Taney. In the rear of this house are the old slave quar-
ters which are well preserved. f

c. “Tomb of Francis Scott Key''—in Mount Olivet Cemetery
—Monument erected through penny contributions from
the children of America.

d. “Hood College’’—founded in 1893. Has a 45-acre cam-

pus.

U. S. Routes No. 15, No. 26, No. 40, No. 240 and No. 340.

“Catoctin Furnace”’—I13 miles north of Frederick—Plates
made here for the first steamboat; cannon balls and shrapnel
used during Revolutionary and Civil Wars were made at
this furnace. U. S. Route No. 5.

“Mount ST. MarY’s CoLLEGE’—near Emmitsburg—founded
in 1808 by Father DuBois, a native of France. In addi-
tion to the high school and college, there is connected with
this institution a theological seminary for young men study-
ing for the priesthood. U. S. Route No. 15.

“BirTurLAcE oF Francis Scorr Key’—at Keysville—monu-
ment here marks the site of the house in which this patriot
was born. g

“WesTERN MArYLAND CoLLEGE’’—Westminster—a co-educa-
tional college developed from a private academy founded in
1860. Has a campus of 100 acres. U. S. Route No., 140
and Maryland Routes No. 27, No. 31 and No. 32. ‘

“Hampron’—two miles north of Towson—home of the Ridge-
lys for over 175 years. Said to be the largest colonial man-
sion in Maryland. h

“MarYLAND CoLLEGE For WomeNn"’—Lutherville—a select col-
lege for women, founded in 1853; has a campus of 25 acres.
Although it las a small enrollment, an average of about
25 States of the Union are represented each year in its stu-
dent body. U. S. Route No. 111,

“Loct Raven Dam”—near Towson, Baltimore County. The
source of Baltimore’s water supply. One of the beauty spots
of Baltimore County.

“BarTLE ofF NorTH PoinT’—where the British were repulsed
by General Stricker in the War of 1812. The most historic
spot remaining of the eflective and disconcerting entrench-
ment, which ran from Hampstead Hill to the Johns Hopkins
Hospital, and which was built up by the devoted labors of
the citizens of Baltimore on the Sunday and Monday preced-
ing the arrival of the British, is the semi-circular earthworks
aNt Hzampstead Hill (now Patterson Park). Maryland Route

0. 2,

“Tupor HarL’—about three miles from Bel Air—the home of
Junius Brutus Booth and the birthplace of Edwin Booth and
John Wilkes Booth. Contains an interesting collection of
relics and pictures.

“Mepicar Harr’—about seven miles from Bel Air—the home
of Dr. John Archer, the first medical graduate in America.
U. S. Route No. 1.

“Havre pt Grace Race Track”-—at Havre de Grace—con-
sidered the most popular horse racing center of the East.
Spring and Fall programs. U. S. Route No, 40.

“SusQUEHANNA Fprats”—near Havre de Grace—noted for its
fine duck hunting.

“ApiNcpoN"’—on the old post road—birthplace of Wm. Paca,
twice Governor of Maryland and a signer of the Declaration
of Independence. U. S. Route No. 40.

WESTERN MARYLAND

“Soutn Mountain"’—10 miles northwest of Frederick—re-
niembered for the great battle of the Civil War which was
fought there on September 14, 1862. U. S. Route No. 40.

“HarPEr’s FErrY’—where three States and two rivers meet.
Rggolent with Civil War memories, especially John Brown's
raid.

a. “Jefferson's Rock”—Harper's Ferry. It was the sight from
this rock which impelled Thomas Jefferson to remark that
“The scene is worth a voyage across the Atlantic.”

U. S. Route No. 340.

“CrysTAL GrorToEs”’—at Boonsboro—one of the natural won-
ders of the Blue Ridge Mountains; so named because the
stalactites which form a beautiful drapery from the roofs of
the caves have a crystal clearness. U. S. Route No. 40.

“Sucar Loa¥ Mountain"—so called by a Swiss nobleman,
Baron Groffenied, who ascended it in search of silver mines
with Martin Chartier, a remarkable Frenchman married to
a Shawnee Indian wife. U. S. Route No. 15.

“ANTIETAM BATTLEFIELD —near Hagerstown—scene of the
bloodiest battle of the Civil War. Maryland Route No.-34.

“WasHnincToN County LiBrARY’—near the Court House in
Hagerstown—here was established the first traveling library in
America, which is still operating. U. S. Routes No. 11 and
No. 40 and Maryland Route No. 60.

Fort Freperick”—near Hagerstown—last remaining fortifi-
cation of the French and Indian Wars,

“Fort CumeerLAND”—at Cumberland—base of operations for
George Washington and General Braddock during the French
and Indian Wars. U, S. Routes No. 40 and No. 220 and
Maryland Routes No. 28 and No. 51.

“Lover’s Leap”’——near Cumberland—a point of interest to all
visitors in this vicinity.

“Tue Narrows’'—just west of Cumberland—one of the Na-
tion’s three natural east-west gateways through the Appa-
lachian Mountains. Maryland Route No. 35.

Tue Beavrirur Cumserranp Varrey, U. S. Route No. 40.

CumBerLAND is located at the eastern edge of the Georges
Creek Coal , mining region, which produces the highest grade
bituminous ‘coal in America, according to U. S. Naval au-
thorities. U. S. Routes No. 40 and No. 220 and Maryland
Route No. 51.

“CasTLEMAN River Bringe’—one mile east of Grantsville.
Built in 1805, oldest stone arch highway bridge in the United
Stnt'es. U. S. Routes No. 40 and 219,

“Tue Cove'—three miles south of Keyser's Ridge—between
Keyser and Oakland. Noted for its natural beauty. U, S.
Route No. 219,

“Deep Creex Lake’’—near Oakland—called “Fisherman’s

Paradise.”” A man-made lake with 64 miles of exquisite

shore line. U. S. Route No. 219,

During the late Winter and early Spring the vicinity of QOak-
land, Grantsville, Bittinger, Gormania and Kitzmiller is the
scene of great maple sugar activity, the product being equal
in richness and flavor to the famous Vermont variety,

“BacksoNE MounTaIiN’"—altitude of 3,340 feet; lighest moun-
tain.in Maryland. U, S. Routes No. 50 and 219,

L E G E N D " The purpose of this map is to indicate to tourists some of the more outstanding
o a complete and comprehensive list, but rather as indicative of the hundreds o

£

oints of historical, scenic and general interest in Maryland. The points of interest selected are not intended as
interesting places scattered throughout the State. It is suggested that tourists wherever possible make inquiries

at all Maryland State Police Sub-Stations for more detailed directions for reaching the various places. ~ For convenience, the State has been divided into four sections: namely,
Eastern Shore, Southern Maryland, North Central, and Western Maryland, and the principal points of interest have been generally located by the indication of either the U. S. or Maryland route numbers.

EASTERN SHORE OF MARYLAND

“Conowingo Dam’’—at Conowingo—second largest hydro-elec-

tric development in the United States. U. S. Route No. 1.

“Port DEeprosiT’”’—on the banks of the Susquehanna River—
renowned as the termination of Capt. John Smith’s voyage of
exploration up the Chesapeake Bay. Home of the Tome In-
stitute, a boys’ school of national reputation.

“Principio FurNAce''—midway between Havre de Grace and
Elkton. One of the first iron furnaces in this Country. U.S.
Route No, 40.

“PArTRingE Hivn”—Evkron—built prior to 1750 by Colonel
Henry Hollingsworth, a noted patriot, who during the Revo-
lutionary War, was engaged in the manufacture of gun barrels
and bayonets for the Council of Safety of Maryland.
U. S. Route No. 40.

“Bounemia ManNour’’—beautiful estate of Augustine Herman,
a Bohemian by birth—the first person to_receive his citizenship
in Maryland by Act of the Assembly. U. S. Route No. 213.

“OLp Surewssury Cuurch’’—near Locust Grove—one of the
thirty parishes- of the Church of England laid out in the
province of Maryland in 1692 by authority of an act of the
provincial assembly. U. S§. Route No. 213,

CHESTERTOWN-—

a. ‘“‘Pearce House''—built in 1735 as a residence for British
customs officials.

b. *“Washington College''—oldest college in Maryland and
eleventh oldest in the United States. First college to bear
the’ name of the Father of OQur Country by his personal
consent.

U. S. Route No. 213.

“St. Luke’s Cuurcn’’—at Church Hill—present church built
in 1730. One of the original parish churches of Maryland.
U. S. Route No. 213 and Maryland Routes No. 300 and

o. 19.

“Winton""—near Melfield—once the. summer home of Judge
Richard Tilghman Earle—now the summer home of Mr. and
Mrs. John J. Raskob of Delaware.

“Wye Oax”’—at Wye Mills just south of Centerville—said to
be over 400 years old and has a spread of 140 feet. U. S.
Route No. 213 and Maryland Route No. 404. !

“Kent Istand”’—Wm, Claiborne established a trading. post
and fort at the southern end of this island in 1631. Lord
Baltimore’s rights were reserved, which led to serious con-
troversy until taken by armed forces in 1637.

“Oup Frienns’ Meerine House”—at Easton—built in 1684
by the Society of Friends and said to be the oldest frame
building dedicated to religious meetings in America. U. S.
Route No. 213 and Maryland Route No. 17.

“Wyr House”’—the home of the Lloyd family for nine genera-
tions, and regarded as one of the show places of Maryland.
Maryland Route No. 17,

“PrLimuiMMon’’—near Easton—the ancestral home of the wife
of Lieut.-Col. Tench Tilghman, who carried the glad tidings
of the surrender of the British at Yorktown to the Conti-
nental Congress at Philadelphia. On this old estate 'is a
monument to Tench Tilghman,

“RarcrLirre Maxnour’’—on the Tred Avon River—a splendid
example of colonial architecture and noted for its boxwood
gardens,

“Frazier’s Frars’'—east of the Choptank River above Dover
Bridge—about five miles east of Easton. One of the finest
specimens of colonial architecture on the Upper Choptank.
U. S. Route No. 213. :

The vicinity of Cambridge is the sportsman’s Mecca; many
summer homes and hunting lodges are located here.

“Summer Home or THeE Duronts'’—near Cambridge.

“Summer Home or WaLTer P. CurysLer’’—near Cambridge.

“Op Trinity Cuurcu”’—-near Cambridge—built about 1665,
familiarly known as ‘“The Old Church.” A handsome red
velvet cushion sent to the church by Queen Anne, and upon
which she is said to have knelt to receive her crown is still
in possession of the church and in a perfect state of preser-
vation,

Here, in the vicinity of Cambridge and Oxford, the Acadians
found a haven of welcome alter their exile from Grand Pre,
Nova Scotia, in 1755. There are many descendants of the
Acadians in Dorchester and Talbot Counties.

Section south of Taylor's Island is center of the muskrat indus-
try, the income from which amounts to approximately
$2,500,000 annually.

“Green HiLn Cuurcu’’-—several miles above White Haven on
the Wicomico River. Built in 1733, one of the original
parish churches laid out in 1692, ;

SaLispury—known as Handy's Landing until 1732, in which
year the town of Salisbury was laid out. There are a num-
ber of old colonial mansions still standing in or near this now
thriving town, among them:

a. ‘‘Pemberton Hall”—about six miles from Salisbury.

b. “‘Cherry Hill’’—about two miles from Salisbury.

c. “‘Poplar Hill Mansion"—facing down Williams Street in
Salisbury.

U. S. Routes No. 13 and No. 213 and Maryland Route

o. 12.

“Wasuiveron Hoter—Princess Anne—built by John Done
on lot No. 15, when Princess Anne was laid out in lots be-
fore the Revolutionary War. An interesting feature of this
old inn, a survival of Colonial days, is the double staircase—
one for the ladies whose large hoop skirts required abundant
space and the other for the gentlemen who admired them
from a respectful distance, ascending and descending. U. S.
Route No. 13,

“Cuase House”——about two miles south of Princess Anne—
built in 1713; the birthplace of Samuel Chase, one of the
signets of the Declaration of Independence.

“DeaL IsLanp”—in Somerset County—one of the greatest sec-
tions in the Country for hunting wild fowl. Here also is the
soft crab center of the world.

“TANGIER Sounp’’—greater part of this famous sound ‘lies
within Somerset County—this body of water produces more
valuable sea foods than any similar waters in the Country.

“CrisFierp”’—in Somerset County—the crabbing center of the
United States. Here the famous Maryland Crab is caught,
packed and shipped to all parts of the Country. Crisfield is
noted also for its Diamond Back Terrapin nurseries. Here
thousands of this rare Maryland delicacy are raised and
shipped to every State in the Union. U, S. Route No. 413.

“Art Harrows Cuurcu’’~—at Snow Hill—built in 1748, U. S.
Route No. 113 and Maryland Route No. 12,

“Ocean City”"—Maryland’s well-known seaside resort. Has
a summer population of over a half million persons., U. S.
Route No. 213.

*“CHINCOTEAGUE IsLAnD’—on the eastern shore of Virginia
near the Maryland line—noted for its wild ponies. A round-
up and sale is held on the island annually and draws inter-
ested spectators and buyers from all parts of the East. Chinco-
teague Bay is also noted for its salt oysters. Maryland Route

0. 13,
SOUTHERN MARYLAND

ANNAPOLIS—

a. “United States Naval Academy’—established in 1845 by
George Bancroft, then Secretary of the Navy,

b. “St. John's College’—originally King Wil{iam’s School ;
founded in 1696,

c. “Liberty Tree”’—on the campus of St. John's College—a
tulip poplar 150 feet high, said to be: years old.

d. “Hammond-Harwood House’'—built in 1777; one of the
finest examples of Georgian architecture in America.

e. “Paca House”—built in 1763 by Wm. Paca, one of the
signers of the Declaration of Independence. Now known
as Carvel Hall Hotel, °

f. *“Brice House’—built in 1745. Regarded as the hand-
somest house in a city of handsome old homes.

g. ‘‘State House''—here, on December 23, 1783, Washington
surrendered his commission to the Continental Congress.
Here also, Congress ratified the treaty with Great Britain
at the close of the Revolutionary War.

h. *St. Anne’s Church”~—built in 1699. Among its treasures
are the silver communion set presented by King William
III and the beautiful Sand’s Memorial Window in the
Nave, which, when exhibited by Tiffany at the Chicago
World’s Fair, won first prize for ecclesiastical art.

“Old State Treasury Building”’—built in 1694.

‘‘Home of Anthony Stewart’’—owner of the brig “Peggy

Stewart.”

“White Hall’’~—near Annapolis—one of the most famous

homes in Southern Maryland. Built in 1760, the sum-

mer home of Horatio Sharpe, one of the earliest Gov-

ernors of Maryland. g
U. 8. Route No, 50 and Maryland Route/No. 2.

“ALr Harrows Chnukcu’—on the State Road from Annapolis
to Solomons. Built about 1692, Maryland Route No. 2.
“St. James’ Cuurcu''—at Herring Creek—about four miles
low Mt. Zion. Built about 1694, one of the original parish
churches of Maryland. Rebuilt in 1763 and present building

is still in use., Maryland Route No. 2.

“Laurer Race Track”—one of the finest tracks in the Coun-
try—where horse racing meets are held each Fall. U. S.
Route No. 1.

“University oF MaryrLanp”’—College Park—founded by the
merging in 1920 of the University of Maryland which was
founded in 1807 and the Maryland State Agricultural Col-
lege founded in 1856. Has campus of 300 acres and a farm
of 210 acres belonging to the college of agriculture, U, S.
Route No. 1.

“BLApENSBURG —where the American forces, composed of 500
seamen and marines with five pieces of artillery, under the
command of Commodore Joshua Barney, attempted to hold in
check the British army of veterans more than 5,000 strong.
U. S. Routes No. 1 and No. 50. -3

“GreenpeLt Community (Tucwerrtown)'’—project of the
Resettlement Administration at Berwyn, U. S. Route No. 1.

“BeLAir”'—near Bowie—the old Governor Ogle place. It still
has all the features of an old English estate, with its park,
private race track and kennels.

“Bowie Race Track”—one of Maryland’s four famous tracks—
where horse racing programs are held annually in the Spring
and Fall,

“OLp Marrooro House”—Upper Marlboro. About 250 years
old. Maryland Routes No. 3 and No. 4.

“St. Pauvr’s Cuurcu’’—at Baden—built about 1694. An in-
teresting relic is a marble font said to have been presented
by Queen Anne and is still in use. Bishop Claggett, first
Bishop of the Episcopal Church to be ordained in America,
was twice rector of this church.

“Murperry Grove”’—near La Plata—home of John Hanson,
president of the first Continental Congress, which welcomed
General Washington officially on his return from receiving
the surrender of Cornwallis. Maryland Route No. 3.

Southern Maryland is noted for its excellent tobacco, and
tobacco raising is an important industry of the State. The
approximate value of the 1931 crop is estimated at about
$9,000,000.

“St., Tuomas’ Cuurcu AND. Burvine Grounp’’—at Chapel
Point—first home of the Jesuit priests in America.

“Curist Cuurcn’’—at Port Republic—built of bricks im-
ported from England in 1732. Maryland Route No. 2.

P
.

r

“Mipprenam CuareL’’——about six miles from Solomons—built
in 1699, one of the original parish churches of Maryland. The
bell in this church is the third oldest on the Atlantic seaboard
and was a gift of a British nobleman. Maryland Route

0. 2,

“Soromoxs IsrLanp”’—the harbor at Solomons is one of the
deepest natural harbors in the world, reaching a depth of
136 feet, and is an important center of the yacht and boat
building industry. The Dewey floating drydock was built
an tested here because there was no other harbor in the East
large enough for its construction. Solomons is considered
one of the finest” “fishing grounds” in the East. Maryland
Route No. 2.

“Tue Crirrs or CALvErT” —rise vertically from the Bay and
extend for 30 miles from Chesapeake Beach to Drum Point—
these cliffs contain fossiliferous strata of from ten to twenty
feet in thickness. :

“CrarLorte HaLn ScHoovr”—on the State Road to Leonard-
town. In 1774, the free schools of St. Mary’s, Charles and
Prince George's Counties - were united and Charlotte Hall
erected, Maryland Routes No. 5 and No. 6.

“Curist Crurcn’’—at Chaptico—one of the original parish -

churches of Maryland. Designed by Sir Christopher Wren,

the architect of St. Paul’s Cathedral, London. Maryland

Route No. 234. ;

“Porrar Hirr Cuurcu'’—at Valley Lee—about 12 miles from
Leonardtown. Oldest parish church in Maryland.

St. Mary’s Crry— s
a. “Chancellor’s Point’’—near St. Mary’s City—where the

“Ark” and the “Dove” landed in 1634. At a spot
near here, Leonard Calvert laid out St. Mary's City, the
first colony in Maryland. :

b. “Leonard Calvert Monument”—St. Mary's City—on the
site of the old mulberry tree under which Leonard Calvert
signed the treaty by which he bought 30 miles from the
Indian King in § . ; :

¢. “Trinity Church’—at St. Mary’s City—built of the bricks
of the first State House in Maryland on the site of the
old mulberry tree under which negotiations were made
between Leonard Calvert and King Yaocomico. The altar
and communion rail were made from the wood of the
old tree.

Maryland Route No. 5. : 3

“Cross Manor”—below St. Inigoes—built in 1642 by Thomas
Cornwaleys, Deputy Governor of Maryland. Said to be the
oldest house in the State, and noted for its boxwood hedges
nearly 300 years old, Maryland Route No. 5.

“Sr. Inicoes CHurcu’’—about two miles from St. Inigoes—
the oldest Catholic church in Maryland. The original church
property of 2,000 acres is still retained by the Jesuit Order.
Maryland Route No. §. )

“Point Looxoutr”’—0On the southeastern tip of St. Mary’s land,
where the Potomac flows into the Chesapeake. Maryland
Route No. 5. ’

NORTH CENTRAL MARYLAND

“DovcorEGAN Manor’'—near Ellicott City—beautiful old
colonial mansion. Ancestral home of Charles Carroll of Car-
rollton, a signer of the Declaration of Independence. U. S.
Route No. 40.

“Oriver Viapuct”’—at Ellicott City, a part of the original
Baltimore and Ohio Railroad line—the cornerstone for this
triple-arch structure was laid in 1829 and the bridge was
formally opened to traffic in 1830. During the same year,
the “Tom Thumb,” first steam engine in America, crossed
this bridge on its first trip, from Baltimore to Ellicott Mills,
U. S. Routes No. 40 and No. 29.

“BrookeviLLE —President Madison and his family took refuge
in this quaint old town when the British burned the city
of Washington in 1814, and the house which they occupied
is still standing. Maryland Route No. 97.

“Rockx Creek Park”—this lovely park, which begins in Wash-
ington, extends into Montgomery County. In this park is
located the United States National Zoological Gardens, con-
taining one of the most complete collections of wild animals,
reptiles, birds, fowl, etc., in the world.

“Greatr Fairs or THeE Poromac’’—In the rugged country of
Montgomery County, about 15 miles from Washington, the
river makes its most rapid descent in a series of beautiful
falls, and is unrivaled for scenic beauty in this section of
the Country.

FreEpERICK— ¢
a, “‘Home of Barbara Fritchie””—Here this famous character

of Civil War days lived “‘bowed with her four score years
and ten,” and by her intense patriotism inspired Whittier
to write “‘Barbara. Fritchie.” ,

b. ‘“The Taney House’’—home of Chief Justice Roger Brooke
Taney. In the rear of this house are the old slave quar-
ters which are well preserved. f

c. “Tomb of Francis Scott Key''—in Mount Olivet Cemetery
—Monument erected through penny contributions from
the children of America.

d. “Hood College’’—founded in 1893. Has a 45-acre cam-

pus.

U. S. Routes No. 15, No. 26, No. 40, No. 240 and No. 340.

“Catoctin Furnace”’—I13 miles north of Frederick—Plates
made here for the first steamboat; cannon balls and shrapnel
used during Revolutionary and Civil Wars were made at
this furnace. U. S. Route No. 5.

“Mount ST. MarY’s CoLLEGE’—near Emmitsburg—founded
in 1808 by Father DuBois, a native of France. In addi-
tion to the high school and college, there is connected with
this institution a theological seminary for young men study-
ing for the priesthood. U. S. Route No. 15.

“BirTurLAcE oF Francis Scorr Key’—at Keysville—monu-
ment here marks the site of the house in which this patriot
was born. g

“WesTERN MArYLAND CoLLEGE’’—Westminster—a co-educa-
tional college developed from a private academy founded in
1860. Has a campus of 100 acres. U. S. Route No., 140
and Maryland Routes No. 27, No. 31 and No. 32. ‘

“Hampron’—two miles north of Towson—home of the Ridge-
lys for over 175 years. Said to be the largest colonial man-
sion in Maryland. h

“MarYLAND CoLLEGE For WomeNn"’—Lutherville—a select col-
lege for women, founded in 1853; has a campus of 25 acres.
Although it las a small enrollment, an average of about
25 States of the Union are represented each year in its stu-
dent body. U. S. Route No. 111,

“Loct Raven Dam”—near Towson, Baltimore County. The
source of Baltimore’s water supply. One of the beauty spots
of Baltimore County.

“BarTLE ofF NorTH PoinT’—where the British were repulsed
by General Stricker in the War of 1812. The most historic
spot remaining of the eflective and disconcerting entrench-
ment, which ran from Hampstead Hill to the Johns Hopkins
Hospital, and which was built up by the devoted labors of
the citizens of Baltimore on the Sunday and Monday preced-
ing the arrival of the British, is the semi-circular earthworks
aNt Hzampstead Hill (now Patterson Park). Maryland Route

0. 2,

“Tupor HarL’—about three miles from Bel Air—the home of
Junius Brutus Booth and the birthplace of Edwin Booth and
John Wilkes Booth. Contains an interesting collection of
relics and pictures.

“Mepicar Harr’—about seven miles from Bel Air—the home
of Dr. John Archer, the first medical graduate in America.
U. S. Route No. 1.

“Havre pt Grace Race Track”-—at Havre de Grace—con-
sidered the most popular horse racing center of the East.
Spring and Fall programs. U. S. Route No, 40.

“SusQUEHANNA Fprats”—near Havre de Grace—noted for its
fine duck hunting.

“ApiNcpoN"’—on the old post road—birthplace of Wm. Paca,
twice Governor of Maryland and a signer of the Declaration
of Independence. U. S. Route No. 40.

WESTERN MARYLAND

“Soutn Mountain"’—10 miles northwest of Frederick—re-
niembered for the great battle of the Civil War which was
fought there on September 14, 1862. U. S. Route No. 40.

“HarPEr’s FErrY’—where three States and two rivers meet.
Rggolent with Civil War memories, especially John Brown's
raid.

a. “Jefferson's Rock”—Harper's Ferry. It was the sight from
this rock which impelled Thomas Jefferson to remark that
“The scene is worth a voyage across the Atlantic.”

U. S. Route No. 340.

“CrysTAL GrorToEs”’—at Boonsboro—one of the natural won-
ders of the Blue Ridge Mountains; so named because the
stalactites which form a beautiful drapery from the roofs of
the caves have a crystal clearness. U. S. Route No. 40.

“Sucar Loa¥ Mountain"—so called by a Swiss nobleman,
Baron Groffenied, who ascended it in search of silver mines
with Martin Chartier, a remarkable Frenchman married to
a Shawnee Indian wife. U. S. Route No. 15.

“ANTIETAM BATTLEFIELD —near Hagerstown—scene of the
bloodiest battle of the Civil War. Maryland Route No.-34.

“WasHnincToN County LiBrARY’—near the Court House in
Hagerstown—here was established the first traveling library in
America, which is still operating. U. S. Routes No. 11 and
No. 40 and Maryland Route No. 60.

Fort Freperick”—near Hagerstown—last remaining fortifi-
cation of the French and Indian Wars,

“Fort CumeerLAND”—at Cumberland—base of operations for
George Washington and General Braddock during the French
and Indian Wars. U, S. Routes No. 40 and No. 220 and
Maryland Routes No. 28 and No. 51.

“Lover’s Leap”’——near Cumberland—a point of interest to all
visitors in this vicinity.

“Tue Narrows’'—just west of Cumberland—one of the Na-
tion’s three natural east-west gateways through the Appa-
lachian Mountains. Maryland Route No. 35.

Tue Beavrirur Cumserranp Varrey, U. S. Route No. 40.

CumBerLAND is located at the eastern edge of the Georges
Creek Coal , mining region, which produces the highest grade
bituminous ‘coal in America, according to U. S. Naval au-
thorities. U. S. Routes No. 40 and No. 220 and Maryland
Route No. 51.

“CasTLEMAN River Bringe’—one mile east of Grantsville.
Built in 1805, oldest stone arch highway bridge in the United
Stnt'es. U. S. Routes No. 40 and 219,

“Tue Cove'—three miles south of Keyser's Ridge—between
Keyser and Oakland. Noted for its natural beauty. U, S.
Route No. 219,

“Deep Creex Lake’’—near Oakland—called “Fisherman’s

Paradise.”” A man-made lake with 64 miles of exquisite

shore line. U. S. Route No. 219,

During the late Winter and early Spring the vicinity of QOak-
land, Grantsville, Bittinger, Gormania and Kitzmiller is the
scene of great maple sugar activity, the product being equal
in richness and flavor to the famous Vermont variety,

“BacksoNE MounTaIiN’"—altitude of 3,340 feet; lighest moun-
tain.in Maryland. U, S. Routes No. 50 and 219,
